title: A case of autovectorization making performance worse

labels.name: I-slow
labels.description: Problems and improvements with respect to performance of generated code.

body:
This issue shows up in a benchmark from this crate: https://github.com/oconnor663/blake2b_simd

```
git clone https://github.com/oconnor663/blake2b_simd
cd blake2b_simd/benches/cargo_bench/
cargo +nightly bench bench_blake2b_portable_compress
```

That benchmark tests an implementation of the BLAKE2b hash function in pure Rust, written without any explicit SIMD. (The crate contains a SIMD implementation, but this benchmark is testing the non-SIMD one, defined in `src/portable.rs`.)

When I run the commands above, my laptop (i5-8250U) shows 165 ns/iter pretty consistently. However, if I set `RUSTFLAGS="-C target-cpu=native"` or `RUSTFLAGS="-C target-cpu=skylake"` and rerun it, then performance drops 30% to 214 ns/iter. You can see the result of autovectorization here (with the relevant code tweaked to avoid depending on external crates): https://godbolt.org/z/Mg86_h. Are perf issues like this expected, or does it indicate some kind of bug in the optimizer?

Notably, if I target the modern processor but suppress vectorization, with something like `RUSTFLAGS="-C target-cpu=skylake -C target-feature=-avx2"`, performance is great. I get 155 ns/iter. So it seems like the vectorizer is specifically at fault here, and not something else about targeting the modern CPU.
